channel.title: What's possible?
channel.description:
Since we certainly can't anticipate what exactly WILL happen on October 25, we can certainly predict what the [b]possible[/b] course of actions are for Jagex. What are your opinions? Most of you are very experienced in Java/RS Cheating, so I expect quality ;) .
One easy move for Jagex would be to implement SecurityManagaer with a strict policy - this would in effect cripple to use of reflection, correct?
What about things like ASM/BCEL? How would one secure themselves against that sort of attack?

item.title: What's possible?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Nueb35, post:124, topic:419120”]Sounds like rule 34…

did anyone confirm that it was per IP and not per country or another factor?[/quote]

Of course we don’t know EXACTLY what it is based on, it could be based on a combo of user-agent, IP, country, and type of computer for all we know, any information that Jagex has access to. But it has been confirmed that some IPs give the same client, and other ones don’t.

For example, from my personal tests (most of which is at moparisthebest.com/rs)
Sometimes my IP in the UK and the Netherlands grabs the same client, but not most of the time.
I also get a different client from my home in Franklin, Ohio (near Cincinnati), than from my server in Chicago, IL.

So, your guess is as good as anything else, but I’d say it was at least somewhat based on IP.

Read full topic

item.title: What's possible?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:119, topic:419120”][quote author=t4 link=topic=521652.msg3804892#msg3804892 date=1320366942]

Jagex seems to be on an updating roll, the last one lasted less than a day.

if i recall, they updated 3 times in a day recently. were there any client changes? or was it just bugfixes?
[/quote]

It doesn’t look like they ever updated even twice in the same day:

https://www.moparisthebest.com/rs/update.log

unless it was in less than an hour and they didn’t change the version number. Though if you keep the client loaded for more than 4 or 6 hours it tells you runescape updated, when they really didn’t. People at SRL have been reporting that.

As to what changed, I haven’t looked.[/quote]
Perhaps that is what I’ve been experiencing.

Read full topic

item.title: What's possible?
item.dc:creator: @Wizzup Wizzup?
item.description:
@Wizzup wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:102, topic:419120”]Just added version checking to the getRS.sh script, and cringe all you want, but I did it with grep, as a bash one-liner. 

get_rs_version(){
	jar_file=$1
	# that's right, I'm parsing bytecode with grep, deal with it, explanations to follow:
	# javap: get the bytecode for client in text
	# egrep: only look for *push or *const, 3 digits, starting with 6 or 7 for now (will have to up that number later)
	# sed: delete everything before the number
	# egrep -v: we don't want certain numbers that appear in every client, like 640 and 765 for now
	# sort | uniq: remove duplicates
	# head -n1: we should be down to the version number anyhow, but just take the first in case it messes up and there are duplicates
	javap -classpath $jar_file -c client | egrep "(push|const)[[:space:]][6-7][0-9]{2}$" | sed "s/^.*[[:space:]]//" | egrep -v "(640|765)" | sort | uniq | head -n1
}

Anyone see anything wrong with that?[/quote]

Just ran into this: http://www.codinghorror.com/blog/2009/11/parsing-html-the-cthulhu-way.html

Read full topic

item.title: What's possible?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:107, topic:419120”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=521652.msg3798213#msg3798213 date=1319828486]
Just added version checking to the getRS.sh script, and cringe all you want, but I did it with grep, as a bash one-liner. 

get_rs_version(){
	jar_file=$1
	# that's right, I'm parsing bytecode with grep, deal with it, explanations to follow:
	# javap: get the bytecode for client in text
	# egrep: only look for *push or *const, 3 digits, starting with 6 or 7 for now (will have to up that number later)
	# sed: delete everything before the number
	# egrep -v: we don't want certain numbers that appear in every client, like 640 and 765 for now
	# sort | uniq: remove duplicates
	# head -n1: we should be down to the version number anyhow, but just take the first in case it messes up and there are duplicates
	javap -classpath $jar_file -c client | egrep "(push|const)[[:space:]][6-7][0-9]{2}$" | sed "s/^.*[[:space:]]//" | egrep -v "(640|765)" | sort | uniq | head -n1
}

Anyone see anything wrong with that?
[/quote]

why, just…why?[/quote]
what do you suggest, oh swami?

Read full topic

@moparisthebest wrote:

Just added version checking to the getRS.sh script, and cringe all you want, but I did it with grep, as a bash one-liner. 

get_rs_version(){
	jar_file=$1
	# that's right, I'm parsing bytecode with grep, deal with it, explanations to follow:
	# javap: get the bytecode for client in text
	# egrep: only look for *push or *const, 3 digits, starting with 6 or 7 for now (will have to up that number later)
	# sed: delete everything before the number
	# egrep -v: we don't want certain numbers that appear in every client, like 640 and 765 for now
	# sort | uniq: remove duplicates

	javap -classpath $jar_file -c client | egrep "(push|const)[[:space:]][6-7][0-9]{2}$" | sed "s/^.*[[:space:]]//" | egrep -v "(640|765)" | sort | uniq | head -n1
}

item.title: What's possible?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:94, topic:419120”]Had to do a lot of searching to find the functionality to match a regex in bash (not a whole line!), even went to freenode #bash, and then when I came up with a solution for my own problem (grep -o) I had to endure hours of being cussed out and belittled for using a GNU extension to grep (-o isn’t supported by non-gnu grep) instead of the proper solution, which they told me is to use a real programming language with a proper HTML DOM inspector, because that totally isn’t complete overkill or anything. Say all you want about this community, but it’s certainly better than THAT.

Anyhow, now I follow links and parse the URL manually, so unless they majorly change the way they do things, this shouldn’t break. I also put in the proper referer header as well with all the requests. They shouldn’t be able to tell the difference between this and a browser with javascript turned off. Of course if it does break, let me know. (I also check for wget errors, so that shouldn’t happen again.)

Enjoy:
https://www.moparisthebest.com/rs/getRS.sh

And, back on topic, did anyone see if anything changed with the new update?
https://www.moparisthebest.com/rs/gamepack/gamepack11-10-27_18.jar[/quote]
#bash bash

frank_:

could be bugfixes, could be panic that jacmob is progressing

like what?

Read full topic
